contentrichtext.text: '''''Right Now!''''' was a [[right wing]] British political magazine, which ran from 1993 to 2006. The magazine also featured arts coverage and cultural criticism. It proclaimed itself a magazine of "politics, ideas and culture". It was initially edited by Michael Harrison, and then from 1995 until closure by [[Derek Turner (journalist)|Derek Turner]]. Contributing editors included Allan Robertson and Christopher Luke<ref>Issues 16 (1997) to 38, with Robertson continuing until Issue 46 (2004)</ref> of the [[Swinton Circle]] and Stuart Millson of the [[Conservative Democratic Alliance]].<ref>from Issue 39 (2003)</ref> Its origins lay in the [[Revolutionary Conservative Caucus]] and with right-wing members of the [[Monday Club]].<ref>[http://www.ferris.edu/HTMLS/othersrv/isar/archives2/genewar/ritenow.htm republished ''Searchlight'' article from 1998] </ref> The magazine featured interviews with and articles by many leading politicians, thinkers and writers. These include [[Antony Flew]], [[Roger Scruton]], [[Pat Buchanan]], [[Peter Brimelow]], [[Frederick Forsyth]], [[Charles Moore (journalist)|Charles Moore]], [[Garry Bushell]], [[Nick Griffin]], [[Jean-Marie Le Pen]], [[Alain de Benoist]], [[Richard Lynn]], [[J. Philippe Rushton]], [[Thomas Fleming (author)|Thomas Fleming]], [[Samuel T. Francis]] and [[C. B. Liddell]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} Prominent [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative politicians]] who contributed to, or were interviewed by, ''Right Now!'' include [[Norman Tebbit]], [[Ann Widdecombe]], [[John Redwood]], [[Teddy Taylor]], [[Teresa Gorman]] and [[Bill Cash]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} The magazine was mentioned by then Foreign Secretary [[Robin Cook]] in 2000 in an attack on then [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] leader [[William Hague]]'s inability to contain "extremists" within the party; Cook criticised Hague for not shutting the magazine down.<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2000/sep/11/race.immigration ''The Guardian'' 11 September 2000]</ref> [[Andrew Hunter (British politician)|Andrew Hunter]], a former Conservative MP who defected to [[Ian Paisley]]'s [[Democratic Unionist Party]], was a long time patron of the magazine. Hunter ceased links with the magazine in 2002, following pressure from [[Iain Duncan Smith]], stating disagreement with an advert in the magazine for the Conservative Democratic Alliance which was critical of the Conservative Party.<ref>[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/mp-severs-tie-with-farright-magazine-651427.html ''The Independent'' 17 May 2002]</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Right Now!
